abstract.p: Stony Brook University Associate Prof Michael Schwartz letter disputes Sen Jeffrey Klein's January 28 letter on revising laws for sex offenders

block.p: What State Senator Jeffrey D. Klein does not mention in his letter (''Revising Laws for Sex Offenders,'' Jan. 28) is that ''civil commitment'' for sex offenders is a cynical and politically expedient bone thrown to the members of society who are understandably fearful of unprovoked attacks by criminals and psychopaths.

What State Senator Jeffrey D. Klein does not mention in his letter (''Revising Laws for Sex Offenders,'' Jan. 28) is that ''civil commitment'' for sex offenders is a cynical and politically expedient bone thrown to the members of society who are understandably fearful of unprovoked attacks by criminals and psychopaths.

Aside from the few individuals in the sexually violent predator population who have major mental illnesses, these felons do not belong in psychiatric facilities. Indeed if they did, by law they should have been found not responsible for their criminal behavior by reason of mental illness and sent to a forensic hospital, not to prison.
The law is fairly clear that individuals cannot be hospitalized solely for the purpose of confinement and not treatment.

If there are effective treatments for sexual psychopathy, they ought to be rendered early in the course of the prison sentence, not after 15 or 20 years of incarceration, when the release of a sexual offender into the community may cause embarrassment to public officials.

The public mental health system and the employees of that system should not be exploited in an effort to do an ''end run'' around the law. If our legislators feel so strongly about this, then they ought to seek ways to properly amend the law to extend the prison sentences of individuals (and not just sex offenders) who are deemed by actuarial methods to be at high risk of recidivism.
The writer is an associate professor of clinical psychiatry, Stony Brook University School of Medicine.
